title: Tower Research to Pay $67 Million to Settle Spoofing Claims
summary: High-speed trading firm also signs on to deferred prosecution agreement with DOJ. WASHINGTON-High-speed trading firm Tower Research Capital LLC agreed to pay $67 million to settle regulatory allegations that its traders manipulated the price of stock-index futures, the biggest penalty ever imposed by the U.S. derivatives watchdog in such a case.

title: Choosing the Right Earnings Day is a Complex Task for Finance Executives
summary: Thursday is expected to be the busiest day of earnings season, with more than 420 U.S.-listed companies scheduled to report. Thursday was the most popular day to report financial results this earnings season. And, for some companies, that might have been a good thing.

title: Prosecutors Present Text Messages in Effort to Show Stone Lied to Congress
summary: Former Trump adviser had told lawmakers he had no records of communications relevant to their probe of Russian interference in 2016 election. WASHINGTON-Roger Stone exchanged hundreds of emails and text messages with an associate that he told Congress he had no records of communications with, a federal prosecutor showed jurors Thursday, in the second day of the criminal trial for the former adviser to President Trump.

title: T-Mobile to Offer $15 Cellphone Plan
summary: With new prepaid offer, the wireless carrier tries to assure critics Sprint deal won't hurt competition. T-Mobile US Inc. opened a new front in the cellphone pricing wars, unveiling a monthly data plan that starts at $15 as the company responds to critics that its planned merger with Sprint Corp. will lessen competition.

title: CFTC Whistleblower Tips and Awards Fall After Record 2018
summary: The Commodity Futures Trading Commission's whistleblower program has issued 14 awards, totaling more than $100 million, since 2011. The number of tips to-and awards given out by-the Commodity Futures Trading Commission's whistleblower program have fallen from records set last year, according to the regulator's annual report to Congress.

title: Zillow Says Home-Flipping Will Pull In $1 Billion, Lifting Shares
summary: Real estate platform says reselling segment is on pace to become billion-dollar business. Shares of Zillow Group Inc. rose 9% in after-hours trading as the company said its home-flipping business is expected to generate as much as $1.25 billion this year.

title: The Great Confrontation With China
summary: Pence and Pompeo are making the case for a new approach that will outlast this administration.. The Trump administration is heading for a fundamental break with the People's Republic of China. The rupture, if it occurs, will upend almost a half-century of Washington's "engagement" policies. Twin speeches last month by Vice President Mike Pence and Secretary of State Mike Pompeo contained confrontational language rarely heard from senior American officials in public.

title: 'Berezina' Review: Chasing an Epic Fail
summary: A road trip from Moscow to Paris, tracing the route of the French retreat after Napoleon's invasion of Russia.. A bérézina refers, in colloquial French, to "a disastrous situation." The term derives from the name of a river that the French army crossed in November 1812, in retreat from Moscow after Napoleon's ill-fated invasion of Russia. The French crossed the Berezina, in Belarus, but suffered heavy casualties, under siege by a vengeful Russian army. The river entered the lexicon as a synonym for catastrophe-and inspired a road trip 200 years later.

title: Why Nielsen's CEO Says Splitting the Company Will Help Marketers and Agencies
summary: Observers are hopeful, but waiting to see the execution. Nielsen Holdings PLC said the decision to split itself in two and reduce shareholder dividends will create a pair of companies that innovate better and more quickly than before. That will help marketers and media companies that buy Nielsen's measurement and analytics services, according to the company.

title: Eric Holder Takes Virginia
summary: The Democratic plan to dominate state legislatures has its first electoral success.. Analysts are reading Tuesday's tea leaves, predicting what the off-year election results mean for the presidential race. But one victory is beyond dispute. Former Attorney General Eric Holder will be celebrating this week for a decade.

title: Universal Health Care Makes Politics Sick
summary: Why would a president or prime minister want to be responsible for every single patient in the country?. London

title: The Stasi Spies in Seminary
summary: Religion played a complicated but key role in the collapse of East Germany.. East Germany's Communist government opened the Berlin Wall and thus the country 30 years ago Saturday. Geopolitics and economics drove this outcome, but East Germany's religious communities played a complicated, significant and far too often overlooked role.

title: A Centenary for Free Speech
summary: Holmes's dissent in Abrams v. U.S. set the stage for broad First Amendment rights.. Americans may take free speech for granted, but they couldn't do so a century ago. Courts convicted newspapermen, pamphleteers and politicians for nothing more-and sometimes less-than trying to sway the public against U.S. involvement in World War I. On Nov. 10, 1919, the Supreme Court affirmed the conviction of antiwar protesters under a law that made it a crime to "hinder" the war effort. But a dissent in Abrams v. U.S. laid the foundation for today's robust protection of controversial speech.

title: Labor Sides With Big Oil in a Feud With Pittsburgh's Mayor
summary: The dustup is a microcosm of Democrats' difficulty with blue-collar voters, especially in Pennsylvania.. Pittsburgh

title: An Overreach? But Don't Free Lori Loughlin
summary: Ms. Loughlin and her husband are accused of serious crimes. Simply because they are nonviolent doesn't eliminate the seriousness of their acts.. Regarding William McGurn's "Free Lori Loughlin" (Main Street, Nov. 5): Ms. Loughlin and her husband are accused of serious crimes. Simply because they are nonviolent doesn't eliminate the seriousness of their acts. Not only are they accused of lying about their children's qualifications, but they allegedly paid an enormous sum of money to help them succeed and get away with it. They were indicted by the feds in April and charged with laundering their payments through William "Rick" Singer's so-called "charitable foundation." Their alleged crimes, if proven to be true in a court of law, are serious and merit serious jail time.

title: Automation, New Jobs and a Worker's Duty
summary: Workers have a responsibility to provide their employer more value than their paycheck. If they don't, they won't have jobs.. In his closing sentence, Marc Perrone, president of the United Food and Commercial Workers International Union, states: "Businesses have a responsibility to use technology in a way that benefits their customers and the workers who help them every day" (Letters, Nov. 5). No, Marc, workers have a responsibility to provide their employer more value than their paycheck. If they don't, they won't have jobs. That's been my philosophy since my first paid job baling hay for farmers around my hometown in Iowa at age 14.

title: Plant-Based Meat, Costs and Consciences
summary: A significant motivator for many people who are trying to move toward plant-based foods is to reduce animal abuse and the environmental impact of the modern animal-based food industry.. In "'Plant-Based Meat' Is All Hat and No Cattle" (op-ed, Nov. 6), Rick Berman makes some devastating points about the drawbacks of Beyond Meat : 400% more sodium than lean beef, very heavy processing, 40 ingredients including a paint whitener. At my favorite beer and burger joint in Brooklyn, you can find a bigger drawback-ridiculously higher costs. Billy, the owner of two8two Bar & Burger, says he pays more than double the cost per pound for Beyond Meat. Real beef costs him $4 a pound over all, Beyond Meat costs him the equivalent of $8.50 a pound.

title: Green Windmills: Disaster for Birds and Bats
summary: The wind tower project will clear-cut forests on top of the mountains, even though the project will be on a major migratory bird route and the unique scenic divide of the head waters area of both the Delaware and Susquehanna Rivers.. In response to the letter of the Natural Resources Defense Council's Richard Schrader ("Cuomo's Right About Limiting Gas Pipelines," Nov 1): The first law broken by ideologues is the law of unintended consequences. The NRDC supports the couple dozen or so wind turbines on mountain tops in and around Sanford, N.Y. This is even though three bat species have just been placed on the New York state's "special concern" list, even though the most recent Cornell University study concluded that the bird population of the U.S. is in serious decline, even though the Sierra Club publication Desert Record has set out in detail the serious detrimental health effects of infrasound from wind turbines on wildlife and humans, even though the town of Sanford won't receive one kilowatt-hour of electricity from the wind turbines, even though the eight-square-mile project will clear-cut forests on top of the mountains, even though the project will be on a major migratory bird route and the unique scenic divide of the head waters area of both the Delaware and Susquehanna Rivers. The project seeks a "kill permit" for eagles, other birds and bats. Yet Mr. Schrader believes that "all arrows are now pointed in the right direction." Perhaps the NRDC needs a new compass.

title: Sling TV Boosts Dish Subscriber Count
summary: Pay-TV provider posts surprise third-quarter gain in customers, though earnings still fell. Dish Network Corp. posted a surprise customer gain in the third quarter as its internet-TV business overshadowed accounts lost on the satellite side.

summary: Internal memo acknowledges Turkey's Erdogan might not have been stopped by more forceful policies. title: Best-Selling Books Week Ended November 2
summary: With data from NPD BookScan.

title: 'Marriage Story': The Pain of Parting
summary: Noah Baumbach's film about a couple in the throes of divorce feels both personal and universal.. The marvelous paradox of Noah Baumbach's "Marriage Story" is how full of life it is for a tale of two people-Scarlett Johansson's Nicole and Adam Driver's Charlie-going through a kind of death as their marriage comes apart and they contend for custody of their young son, Henry (Azhy Robertson, perfect in the role). One of Charlie's lawyers, a charming geezer named Bert (Alan Alda), puts it more vividly: "Getting divorced with a kid is one of the hardest things to do. It's like a death without a body." Bert also tells Charlie, for no discernible reason, not to expect too much from an old cat shambling around his shabby office. I'd say expect a lot from the movie and you won't be disappointed. It's a life-affirming, profoundly affecting classic.

title: 'Honey Boy' Review: Exorcizing His Daddy Dearest
summary: Shia LaBeouf stars in and wrote the screenplay for this searing autobiographical drama about a son growing up in the shadow of a troubled father. The concept might sound dubious at best. An exceptionally gifted actor known for behaving badly off-screen writes a film about himself as therapy, then plays his father as a man who betrayed his love and blighted his young life. That's what Shia LaBeouf has done in "Honey Boy," but the movie sweeps away all doubts. It's superb in every respect.

title: How Much Fashion Is Too Much Fashion at Work?
summary: In a fall season rife with over-the-top designs, many women are gauging exactly how much they should embrace the more outré trends at the office. JOJO MU HAS been toning down her work wardrobe of late. The 38-year-old content producer recently pivoted from freelancing in New York to a contract gig in the Silicon Valley offices of a major tech company. "I love being overdressed. I think it's the best," Ms. Mu wistfully confessed. She describes her instinctual style as "eclectic," big on frothy tulle and printed dresses. When we spoke, however, Ms. Mu had just changed out of the relatively sober black-and-white ensemble she'd worn on the job that day. "I've only been working here a year," she said, admitting that she's still feeling out office norms. "I think when I start getting more comfortable, I'll wear whatever I want."

title: A Historic Millionaires' Row in Pittsburgh's East End
summary: The Shadyside neighborhood offers luxury residential real estate in an area walkable to a diverse mix of restaurants, shops and cultural events. Tucked into Pittsburgh's East End is Shadyside, a roughly 14,000-person neighborhood that became popular during the mid-1800s. Into the 1900s, wealthy families like the Fricks and Mellons built mansions in the area, many along Shadyside's Fifth Avenue, or "Millionaire's Row." Today the nearly one-square-mile community's Victorian estates and swanky contemporary homes and condos sit alongside tree-lined streets that offer a sense of privacy within Pennsylvania's second biggest city-even though the enclave is within walking distance to some of the metro's top restaurants and shops. The family-oriented atmosphere makes Shadyside a great place to raise kids-and dogs: More than 50 businesses are pooch-friendly.

title: 1989 Wasn't the End of History After All
summary: Liberal democracy in Eastern Europe is facing a new wave of authoritarian challengers.. My earliest political memory is of watching the Berlin Wall fall live on television. title: Ask a Wine Pro: 5 Pressing Questions
summary: Our wine columnist put persistent puzzlers to four trusted wine professionals. Their responses are equal parts helpful and surprising. CERTAIN WINE-RELATED questions-some a bit silly and others more substantial-have nagged at me over the years. They're not exactly wine "peeves," though I have plenty of those. title: Where Are the Classics?
summary: American theater needs to do a better job of balancing new productions with revivals.. The most revealing news of the 2019-20 theatrical season was the announcement last month of a pair of big-ticket revivals, Edward Albee's "Who's Afraid of Virginia Woolf?" and David Mamet's "American Buffalo," both of which are set to open on Broadway next April. What made it so noteworthy is that "Virginia Woolf," first performed in 1962, has already been done there four times, most recently in 2012-13, while "American Buffalo," first performed in 1975, has been done three times, most recently in 2008.

title: How Google Edged Out Rivals and Built the World's Dominant Ad Machine: A Visual Guide
summary: The U.S. is investigating whether the tech giant has abused its power, including as the biggest broker of digital ad sales across the web. Nexstar Media Group Inc., the largest local news company in the U.S., recently tested what would happen if it stopped using Google's technology to place ads on its websites.

title: Smaller U.K. Parties Look to Disrupt Brexit With Election Pacts
summary: With Britain's two-party system crumbling, a clutch of smaller parties are in contention to receive millions of votes. LONDON-As Brexit continues to reshape British politics, the country's smaller political parties are breaking with precedent and pushing for pre-election nonaggression pacts in an effort to maximize their impact on next month's general election.

title: Good News, and Some Bad, on European Mortgage Rates
summary: For buyers of European real estate, rates are far lower than they are in the U.S. But they come with some pretty expensive fine print. With U.S. mortgage rates near historic lows, American buyers can be forgiven for thinking this is as good as it gets. But the mortgage rates in other parts of the world, including many European nations, make U.S. rates look downright usurious. The European Central Bank reported average rates in September for eurozone home-purchase loans with fixed terms of over 10 years at 1.44%. In the U.S., the average rate in September for 15-year mortgages was 3.12%; 30-year loans averaged 3.61%, according to Freddie Mac data.

title: Coca-Cola Takes on LaCroix With Caffeinated Seltzer
summary: Aha is Coke's latest effort to crack a crowded market after its Dasani brand failed to catch on. The maker of LaCroix, beset by falling sales and increased competition, faces another threat: Coca-Cola Co. is launching a new flavored seltzer brand with caffeinated options.

title: Fed Adds $115.14 Billion in Short-Term Liquidity to Markets
summary: Additions include $80.14 billion in overnight repurchase agreement and $35 billion 14-day repo. The New York Fed added $115.14 billion to financial markets via temporary operations on Thursday.

title: Connecticut Telecom Retirees Face Losing Health Benefits
summary: Under new union contract, Frontier Communications ends coverage for some retirees. Struggling broadband provider Frontier Communications Corp. is ending health benefits for some of its retirees in Connecticut, according to the local union.

title: Gorilla Treks in Rwanda: A Bucket-List Must
summary: The country's mountain gorillas are luring an upscale crowd, generating funds that help sustain the rare apes. Finally, a wildly extravagant vacation you can feel good about. I'D BEEN IN Volcanoes National Park, a sliver of jungle in northern Rwanda, for all of 30 minutes, when a fur ball the size of an ottoman came barreling toward me. To be fair, I was on his turf. I had been spying on the fur ball's family-nine mountain gorillas, including the roughly 400-pound patriarch, a massive silverback with a towering forehead and meaty hands twice the width of mine. The apes were scattered around a tangle of tree branches and bamboo stalks rooted on a mud-packed slope, while I'd been lurking about 30 feet away with six other tourists. We all wore shades of fresh-off-the-shelf khaki, with camera-phones or zoom lenses at the ready. A young couple from Mexico City had Go-Pro video cameras strapped to their wrists.

title: WSJ Survey: Economists Split on Causes of Hiring Slowdown
summary: Slightly more respondents cite shortage of workers than cite softening demand for labor.

title: In Today's Auto Industry, Even Toyota Needs Friends
summary: The world's most profitable car manufacturer can't afford electric cars on its own. It is revealing that even Toyota Motor , which makes more profit than any other car maker globally, doesn't feel it can face the future of the auto industry on its own.

title: Stocks to Watch: Qualcomm, Twitter, Ralph Lauren
summary: Here are some of the companies with shares expected to trade actively in Thursday's session. Here are some of the companies with shares expected to trade actively in Thursday's session. Stock movements noted by ticker reflect movements during regular trading hours; premarket trading is specified separately.

summary: On Wednesday night, WSJ. Magazine honored visionaries at the newly reopened Museum of Modern Art. Sometimes, you click right away. "Thank you so much WSJ. for inviting me to introduce my best friend Julianne Moore," said Bette Midler, presenting 2019 Arts & Activism Innovator Moore with her award. "She's been my best friend for nine months."

title: The Items Explorer Robert Ballard Can't Live Without
summary: Oceanographer and explorer Robert Ballard, currently still embarked on an expedition to locate Amelia Earhart's plane, shares a few of his most prized possessions. "On the upper shelf are my Army and Navy caps. During the Vietnam War I volunteered to be a combat infantry officer. Then I was transferred into the Navy, where I remained for 30 years, primarily in naval intelligence, doing highly classified missions. Most people think of me as the guy who found the Titanic [in 1985]. That was a cover for a military operation, which was recently declassified. I was actually exploring two nuclear submarines we lost in the area. The caps are sitting on a model of Alvin, a deep-diving submarine that I landed on the Titanic, before sending a robot down inside. Behind it is an oil painting of the Titanic. On the lower shelf is a black smoker chimney, which we discovered in the Pacific in 1979. They belch out a fluid that's hot enough to melt lead. That helped us explain the chemistry of the world's oceans. The cap and hood on either side of the black smoker signify my academic life-I have 22 honorary doctorates in addition to my Ph.D.-and leaning against it is the Hubbard Medal presented to me by the National Geographic Society. Hanging on the mantel are two more medals, from the Explorers Club. In the corner, that's a tube worm in the glass container. In 1977, we discovered a complex ecosystem of exotic creatures that had figured out, over eons, how to duplicate photosynthesis in the darkness of the ocean. This discovery helps explain the origin of life on earth-and points to the high probability of it existing on other planets, even within our own solar system. The framed photo on top is of two of my children-Todd, on the right, died in a car accident when he was 20. Next to it is a cartoon I published in National Geographic in 1981 that said, We're no longer going to send our bodies to the bottom of the ocean; we are going to use telepresence, with advanced robotics. My wife, a television producer, commissioned the artwork in the front, which captures my existence-the military, academic and exploring parts of my life. I'm a Swiss Army knife in the sense that there are a lot of blades."

title: Toyota Rides Out American Shift to Trucks, SUVs
summary: Car maker reports increased profit and maintains its guidance for the full year as Japanese rivals lower forecasts, partly over concerns about U.S. market. TOKYO-American car buyers' appetite for pickup trucks and sport-utility vehicles keeps growing to once-undreamed of levels, which is generally bad news for Japanese auto makers not named Toyota Motor Corp.

title: Miners Want to Take the Boom and Bust Out of CEO Pay Packages
summary: Companies say contracts that rely too heavily on stock-based bonuses can encourage risky behavior. Global mining companies are re-examining how they pay their chief executives, aiming to diminish the impact of external factors-like swings in commodity prices-that can mask a leader's true performance.

title: California Enjoys Respite From Fires, but More Danger Looms
summary: Lack of rain means the state remains at risk of more potentially deadly wildfires, particularly in Southern California. Just one week after multiple dangerous wildfires were burning on both ends of California, the state is basking under clear, nearly smoke-free skies again. But forecasters say it may be only a brief reprieve from potentially deadly blazes, particularly in the southern half of the state.

title: Blockchain Makes Inroads Into Stock Market's $1 Trillion Plumbing System
summary: Paxos, a blockchain startup, hopes to construct a faster and cheaper way to process stock trades. Technology from the bitcoin world is coming to the trillion-dollar plumbing that underpins the U.S. stock market.

title: Mexico Inflation Holds Steady
summary: Forecasters expect the central bank will cut interest rates again this month. MEXICO CITY-Mexican inflation held steady in October, in line with the central bank's 3% target, leaving the door open for further interest-rate cuts this month.

title: You Probably Need This Appliance
summary: It kneads, mills, juices, extrudes and apparently runs forever. What can't this sturdy Swedish stand mixer do?. MANUFACTURED IN SWEDEN since 1940, the Ankarsrum stand mixer is built for life. This mighty kitchen appliance is equipped with a 7.4-quart stainless-steel bowl that holds up to 11 pounds of dough, and a 600-watt motor that scoffs at the strain of kneading. Since the motor is at the base, no machinery crowds the area above the bowl, allowing an unobstructed view and clearance for adding ingredients. And thanks to an array of Inspector Gadget-type attachments (sold separately), the Ankarsrum can do more than mix. Pop on a citrus press and it becomes a juicer. Lay the machine on its side and you can attach a grain and spice mill, a meat grinder and sausage maker, a blender, or a pasta roller and extruder. The attachments carry a one-year warranty, while the machine itself is guaranteed for seven years-conservative estimates, reportedly. "We regularly get calls from consumers who bought the machine in the 1940s," said CEO Marcus Grimerö. "They run and run." $700, kingarthurflour.com

title: UniCredit Shares Rise Sharply on Profit Rise and Historic Mediobanca Stake Sale
summary: UniCredit's exit from the investment could cascade through corporate Italy. Italy's largest lender, UniCredit SpA, has shed its entire stake in investment bank Mediobanca SpA, a move that ends a 70-year-plus relationship and has the potential to shake up the country's corporate landscape.

title: Banks Don't Know What to Do With Their Branches
summary: Resume Subscription. PHILADELPHIA-It is happy hour at the Capital One near Rittenhouse Square, and drinks are on the house at the Peet's Coffee on the branch's second floor. Staff tell customers to make themselves comfortable.

title: Sri Lankan Clan With China Ties Plots Political Comeback
summary: The Rajapaksa family's prior rule was stained by allegations of human-rights violations and corruption, sparking worries in Western capitals. COLOMBO, Sri Lanka-A controversial political dynasty that made Sri Lanka a centerpiece of China's efforts to expand its influence in Asia and defeated an insurgency is aiming to reclaim power in this island nation.

title: Buttigieg Barnstormers Flock to Iowa to Boost Candidate

title: Why Steve Kerr Loves a Coach in Liverpool
summary: Resume Subscription. Steve Kerr watched the most stirring comeback in European soccer history from a plane. But he was equally captivated by what happened after Liverpool shocked Barcelona in their Champions League semifinal one day last spring. That's when Liverpool's exuberant German manager Jürgen Klopp extolled his players with high praise in his second language.

title: Foreign Money Supports U.S. Stocks' Rally Back to Record Highs
summary: Many foreign investors feel they have no choice but to pile in. Even with U.S. stocks rallying back to all-time highs, adding to the longest bull market on record, many foreign investors feel they have no choice but to pile in.

title: China Reboots Plan to Lure Tech IPOs
summary: Securities regulators and stock-exchange officials could unveil new rules in the coming days. China is making a fresh attempt to attract technology listings, after previous plans to connect overseas-traded behemoths including Alibaba Group Holding Ltd. with mainland investors fizzled.

title: His World Collapsed the Night the Berlin Wall Fell. Then Came the Hard Part.
summary: After the wall came down 30 years ago, a young East German faced life in a new Germany. The smells were foreign to Falk Fleischer. Even the cigarette smoke felt different. He heard Champagne corks popping. A hand flipped his cap off his head. Another pinned a flower to his lapel.

title: In Divided Hong Kong, Apps Help to Avoid Eating With the Enemy
summary: Color-coded maps steer protesters to friendly establishments and prompt shops to take a stand. HONG KONG-In a city split by months of antigovernment protests, consumers now have a way to identify which businesses appear to share their views, putting shops on alert and offering Hongkongers a way to show their colors.

title: LVMH's Fortunes Glisten in Stock Market
summary: Market cap tops $222 billion, placing luxury-goods maker among Europe's most valuable companies. PARIS-Selling handbags, cognac and designer fashion, LVMH Moët Hennessy Louis Vuitton SE has become one of the most valuable companies in Europe.

title: Saudis Back Travis Kalanick's New Startup
summary: The sovereign-wealth fund-also an early investor in Uber-poured $400 million into CloudKitchens in January. Saudi Arabia's sovereign-wealth fund has pumped $400 million into Travis Kalanick's new company CloudKitchens, according to people familiar with the situation, in a deal that could value the operator of so-called ghost kitchens at about $5 billion and reunites the former Uber Technologies Inc. chief with one of his biggest backers.

title: Meet Travis Kalanick's Secret Startup, CloudKitchens
summary: Commissary-kitchen company hopes to capitalize on food-delivery boom. Travis Kalanick had a front-row seat to the food-delivery boom while chief executive at Uber Technologies Inc., thanks to its Uber Eats unit. For his next act, he is trying to capitalize on it through real estate.

title: Baidu's Search for Growth Isn't Over
summary: The former tech star hasn't recovered from an onslaught of new competition for Chinese ad dollars. Good news: Search giant Baidu has become a value play. The bad news is that China's answer to Google is no longer a growth stock.

title: Real-Estate Technology Startup Snapdocs Raises $25 Million to Develop AI Capabilities
summary: Startup will continue improving AI technology for its mortgage processing platform. Real-estate technology startup Snapdocs Inc. has raised $25 million to further improve artificial intelligence on its mortgage processing platform.

title: China Very Publicly Sentences Fentanyl Traffickers to Prison
summary: Beijing shows Washington it is serious about its agreement to clamp down on the drug. XINGTAI, China-China sentenced nine fentanyl traffickers to prison in an apparent demonstration that it is serious about holding up its part of a bargain with Washington.

title: Baidu Reports Loss Tied to Investment in Travel Company
summary: Once known as the Google of China, the search giant has been trailing companies such as Tencent and Alibaba. Baidu Inc. reported a loss in the third quarter tied to a write-down on its investment in a travel company, but the search engine showed early signs of recovering from a brutal first half as its revenue beat expectations.

title: Pensions Venture Into Risky Corners of the Market in Hunt for Returns
summary: Retirement programs are increasing bets on private debt, junk bonds and real estate as negative yields pare asset growth. Some pension-fund managers are venturing further into unusual investment territory as this year's plunge in bond yields makes it harder to find decent long-term returns.

title: Condo Buyers Can Keep Purchases Secret, N.Y. Tax Officials Say in Reversal
summary: Policy shift follows new analysis of state disclosure law and pressure from real-estate community. New York state tax officials are restoring a measure of secrecy for condo owners who buy units without disclosing their names publicly through limited-liability companies, in a reversal of a policy that drew fire from the real-estate industry.

title: Brazil's Supreme Court Deals Setback to Corruption Probes
summary: High court rules that defendants cannot be imprisoned until appeals are exhausted; former President da Silva could be released soon. BRASÍLIA-Brazil's Supreme Court ruled on Thursday that defendants cannot be imprisoned before all their appeals are exhausted, marking a setback for graft investigations that have led to the convictions of dozens of high-ranking politicians and business leaders.

title: House Withdraws Subpoena for Former Bolton Deputy in Impeachment Inquiry
summary: After receiving the congressional subpoena, Charles Kupperman sued, asking a court to decide if he has immunity as the White House claims. WASHINGTON-The House of Representatives withdrew a congressional subpoena for the testimony of former deputy national security adviser Charles Kupperman in the impeachment investigation and asked a federal court to dismiss his lawsuit over the matter.

title: SoftBank's Vision Fund Won't Alter Its Investment Strategy
summary: Fund has drawn scrutiny for its sheer size and its investment strategy. SoftBank Group Corp.'s Vision Fund will do little to change its investment strategy, the fund's finance chief said, despite losses and missteps with We Cos.

title: Sessions Plans to Enter Alabama Senate Race
summary: The former attorney general, who had a public falling out with President Trump in 2018, is hoping to make a return to the Senate. Former Attorney General Jeff Sessions plans to announce a run for his old Senate seat in Alabama on Thursday, according to people familiar with his decision.

title: Attack on Mining Company's Convoy Kills 37 in Burkina Faso
summary: Canadian miner Semafo's buses targeted by gunmen in latest violence to strike African nation. Gunmen attacked a convoy near a Canadian-owned mining site in Burkina Faso, killing at least 37 people and wounding 60 others, the regional governor said late Wednesday.

title: U.S. Collected a Record $7 Billion in Tariffs in September
summary: Tariff revenue jumped 9% from August and was up more than 59% from a year earlier.

title: Fox Revenue Rises on TV Growth, Studio Leasing
summary: Revenue from cable network programming also grew. Fox Corp. said Wednesday its quarterly revenue rose 5%, boosted by strong growth at its television unit and higher proceeds from its Los Angeles studio lot, which the company is leasing to rivals.

title: U.S. Charges Former Twitter Employees With Spying for Saudis
summary: Justice Department says the two former employees accessed information about people who made posts critical of the Saudi royal family. Federal prosecutors charged two former Twitter Inc. employees and a Saudi Arabian national with spying on some users of the social-media platform who were critical of Riyadh and providing that information to the kingdom's officials.

title: Jury to Weigh Reach of U.S. Bribery Law
summary: Jurors have been asked to decide whether a British national who worked for a French company in Paris has sufficient ties to the U.S. to be prosecuted under the U.S. Foreign Corrupt Practices Act. NEW HAVEN, Conn.-A jury is expected to deliberate Thursday in a long-running case that is testing the reach of the U.S.'s foreign bribery law.

title: Injections Can Treat PTSD Symptoms in Veterans
summary: Army-funded clinical trial show troops respond to little-known treatment, relieving sometimes-debilitating effects. A few anesthetic injections to the neck can reduce the effects of PTSD, promising to open up new avenues for treating troops and veterans suffering from combat trauma, a new study shows.

title: Trump, Republican Allies Celebrate Judicial Appointments
summary: The president also complained about judges issuing injunctions that block his policies nationwide. President Trump celebrated his record of judicial appointments at the White House Wednesday, seeking to shift focus from the impeachment process roiling Washington to an issue he sees as a key campaign argument.

title: Uber Shares Hit Record Low as Post-IPO Lockup Expires
summary: Ride-hailing giant's stock has languished since its market debut. Uber Technologies Inc. shares hit an all-time low Wednesday as the "lockup" period following its May initial public offering ended, delivering a blow to a company that has struggled to satisfy investors.

title: German Finance Ministry Signals Support for European Banking Integration
summary: Prospect of a banking union has until now been opposed by Germany. Germany's finance ministry for the first time opened the door to policies that could pave the way for a more unified European banking system, though questions remain over whether the political will exists to push through the long-talked-about overhauls.

title: New Queens, N.Y., Prosecutor Pledges Changes to a Law-and-Order Office
summary: Melinda Katz says she will bring a left-leaning approach to the Queens district attorney's office, where prosecutors have been known for traditional policies. Queens' next top prosecutor, Melinda Katz, has pledged to bring a left-leaning approach to criminal justice in her new job, a challenge in an office that has long been known for its traditional law-and-order policies.

title: Election Results Suggest Limits to Trump's Campaign Influence
summary: President's rallies and tweets for GOP candidates have mixed returns; Democrats take Virginia's legislature, lead in Kentucky governor's race. A Democratic takeover of the Virginia legislature and a potential upset in the Kentucky governor's race put Republicans on the defensive, suggesting limits to President Trump's campaigning power heading into the 2020 election.

title: Colombian Defense Minister Resigns Over Deadly Military Attack
summary: Eight children among more than 15 killed in Aug. 29 military bombing. By evening, the nation's defense minister had submitted his resignation.

title: First Public Hearings in Impeachment Inquiry to Begin Next Week
summary: House panel releases testimony by Ambassador Bill Taylor that security aid to Ukraine was linked to investigations sought by President Trump. title: Qualcomm's Earnings Slump Shows Signs of Easing
summary: Chip maker shipped 152 million chips in the quarter, down 34%, but outlook for global 5G shipments is positive. title: Hope and Despond in Colorado
summary: Voters stood up for tax refunds-but not charter schools.. They didn't make the biggest headlines, but Tuesday's elections in Colorado included two results that deserve national attention. First, a wide margin of voters refused to weaken the state's Taxpayer Bill of Rights, a constitutional provision that prevents state tax collections from outpacing inflation plus population growth.

title: In Roger Stone Trial, Prosecutors Focus On Contacts With Trump Campaign, Wikileaks
summary: Stone is charged with lying to Congress; trial is expected to illuminate workings of Trump's inner circle. WASHINGTON-Roger Stone lied to Congress to shield his longtime friend and associate Donald Trump from embarrassment, federal prosecutors alleged Wednesday at the opening of the political consultant's criminal trial.

title: Iran's Nuclear Escalation
summary: Time for Europe to join the U.S. maximum-pressure campaign.. President Hassan Rouhani has announced that Iran will violate restrictions on the Fordow underground nuclear facility starting Wednesday. President Trump's detractors will say this proves that leaving the 2015 nuclear deal was a mistake, but this is one more sign of the defects in the deal that Europe should be helping the U.S. to address.

title: Dish Picks Nokia, Sprint Veterans for Wireless Venture
summary: Satellite company hires former Nokia executive Marc Rouanne and ex-Sprint technology chief Stephen Bye. Dish Network Corp. appointed two cellular-industry veterans to run its fledgling wireless business, a sign the company is plowing more resources into the venture.
